image.altText: Anthony Albanese, in Akubra and open collar, watches a ceremonial dance

items.synopsis: Twelve months after committing to a Voice referendum during last year's Garma Festival, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is drumming up support for the Yes campaign at this year's festival. Follow live.

title.children: Anthony Albanese tells Garma Festival to 'vote Yes for a better future' in keynote speech

image.altText: Indigenous Australians in traditional dress performing a traditonal dance during an opening ceremony

items.synopsis: When Anthony Albanese confirmed at the Garma Festival 12 months ago that his new government would go ahead with a referendum on Indigenous recognition and an Indigenous Voice, the Arnhem Land air seemed full of optimism. Since then, things have not been going well, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The Voice was supposed to unify Australians. Where has the optimism gone?

image.altText: Shane Drumgold holding a folder walking into ACAT.

items.synopsis: The board of inquiry into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann made damning findings against the DPP, Shane Drumgold, but police didn't emerge unscathed.

title.children: The ACT's top prosecutor sparked the Bruce Lehrmann inquiry. Now he's copping most of its fallout

image.altText: Kiyah sits in the drivers seat of her car, smiling.

items.synopsis: Demand for driving lessons is strong among women, but a lack of female instructors is putting some of them off taking the test.

title.children: Many women prefer to use female driving intructors, and that's holding them back from getting their licences

image.altText: Putin poses against a tree, dressed in outdoorsy clothing

items.synopsis: Russia's president may have placed himself at the pinnacle of a so-called "power vertical", but some believe one "humiliating" weekend could be the beginning of the end for his regime.

title.children: 'Absolute dismay and confusion': A picture is emerging of Putin in crisis. It could threaten his rule

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: In a speech at the Garma Festival, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese promises to hold the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum this year, rejecting calls to delay or cancel it.

title.children: 'We will not deny the urgency of this moment': Albanese promises to hold Voice referendum in 2023

image.altText: auction sign out from of two storey home

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank's mission to bring inflation down to its target range of between 2 and 3 per cent appears to be on track, but how confident of this can we be? Movements in the Australian dollar give us some clues, writes David Taylor.

title.children: What the fall in the Australian dollar tells us about the future of interest rate rises

items.synopsis: There's a common cycle for many children in this town: Crime, watch house, detention. Background Briefing investigates why.

title.children: Marty woke to find three intruders in his bedroom. His story is one of hundreds from his hometown

image.altText: A Wallabies player looks on during a 2022 Test against South Africa in Adelaide.

items.synopsis: The Wallabies open the scoring in the second Bledisloe Cup Test in Dunedin, as they look to salvage pride after three consecutive defeats. Follow our live ScoreCentre.

title.children: Bledisloe Cup live: Wallabies on the board early against All Blacks

image.altText: A bowl of steaming rice.

items.synopsis: The Indian rice export ban, the war in Ukraine and El Niño are combining to create a "doom loop" for the world's poorest people, as staple food prices soar.

title.children: The price of rice is skyrocketing, and it's pushing millions more people towards starvation

image.altText: Black and white photo of men near satellite

items.synopsis: Voyager 2 was exploring interstellar space 19 billion kilometres away from Earth when an erroneous command caused it to tilt its antenna way from earth.

title.children: NASA restores contact with missing Voyager 2 spacecraft after weeks of silence

image.altText: A woman holds Australian flags at a soccer match.

items.synopsis: An Adelaide mother whose urgent need for rare blood sparked an international search for matching donors now has access to enough supply to make critical surgery possible, Lifeblood says.

title.children: International search secures enough blood for Adelaide mum Amira ahead of surgery

image.altText: An elderly male actor on a red carpet, looks expressionless towards photographers

items.synopsis: Margolis was nominated for an Emmy in 2012 for Breaking Bad, as Hector, the elderly don of his drug clan who was unable to speak or walk due to a stroke.

title.children: Mark Margolis, who played murderous drug kingpin on Breaking Bad, dies at 83

image.altText: a man and a woman smile at the camera standing in front of a triple j sign

items.synopsis: Owen Wright was at the top of his game when he suffered a massive wipe-out that resulted in bleeding on the brain. With help from his partner, singer-songwriter Kita Alexander, he made an incredible comeback.

title.children: 'It knocked the lights out of me': Surfer Owen Wright on the moment that changed his life

image.altText: The Russian Navy's large landing ship Olenegorsky Gornyak underway at night.

items.synopsis: A Russian warship is reportedly seriously damaged by a Ukrainian naval drone during an attack on Russia's Black Sea navy base in Novorossiysk, east of Crimea.

title.children: Ukrainian air and sea drones attack Black Sea navy base and Crimea

image.altText: A man in a football helmet runs with a ball.

items.synopsis: It was a hit that saw NRL fans calling for Jarome Luai to be sidelined, but the Panthers star has somehow escaped suspension. Here's why.

title.children: How Panthers star Jarome Luai escaped suspension for his high shot on Storm star

image.altText: A woman in a heavy coat and a beanie crosses her hands with index fingers pointed as she sits next to a grinning man in a jacket

items.synopsis: Europe and parts of north and south America are in the middle of a vicious heatwave, and the world recorded its hottest July on record — but in the Pacific, puffer jackets are becoming the norm as Tonga shivered through its second-coldest temperature on record.

title.children: Puffer jackets in the Pacific Islands — what is going on with the weather?

image.altText: A soccer player wearing red and white uniform leans on her hands and knees during a game

items.synopsis: Over the past 18 months, more than 120 women footballers have suffered ACL injuries. FIFA is trying to figure out why.

title.children: 'I was devastated': Why football's best players aren't at the 2023 Women's World Cup

image.altText: Matildas fans show support during a 'Send Off Match' between Australia and France

items.synopsis: The tournament and the love being shown for the world game by the young fans drew an immediate contrast with how the AFL supports its own women's league, writes Virgina Trioli.

title.children: Matildas fans have a message: Disrespect women and it's your loss

image.altText: A man in his early fifties is creating a tattoo on the back of another man in his studio using a bamboo stick

items.synopsis: Thousands of years before it was a modern Western fashion statement, tattooing happened for a very different reason.

title.children: Japan has a long history with hand-carved tattoos. But here's why you're unlikely to see them in public

image.altText: Two men walk off a footy field arm in arm.

items.synopsis: Marlion Pickett appeared to deliberately knock a fan's drink over after the supporter slapped the Tiger on the shoulder after a Bulldogs goal.

title.children: AFL set to investigate after fan touches Marlion Pickett over the fence at Docklands

image.altText: A close up photo of a woman in elasticated waist pants holding her hands on her stomach

items.synopsis: Over time, sucking in your stomach can lead to hourglass syndrome, a condition that can cause changes in the appearance of the stomach — and may also affect other parts of the body, writes Adam Taylor.

title.children: Be wary of sucking your stomach in all the time — you could end up with hourglass syndrome

image.altText: A police crime scene.

items.synopsis: A man has died after he was shot multiple times while walking along a street in South Yarra, in Melbourne's inner south-east. Police say the man appears to have been targeted and had links to organised crime.

title.children: Police confirm Melbourne shooting victim had links to organised crime

image.altText: Three men sprint around a velodrome on their bikes.

items.synopsis: Leigh Hoffman, Matt Richardson and Matt Glaetzer claim silver in Glasgow after a back and forth battle with the Netherlands.

title.children: Dutch team dethrones Aussie men in cycling time trial after spectacular battle

image.altText: Pharmacist hands holding a slim box of pills

items.synopsis: A long-awaited trial of over-the-counter sales of emergency contraceptives is underway in Japan, but activists worry access to this essential medicine might only be temporary.

title.children: Japan finally trials over-the-counter sales of morning-after pill — but there's a catch

image.altText: A composite image showing two physicists and the Nagasaki mushroom cloud.

items.synopsis: The story of the first nuclear weapons is, in some respects, the story of a human chain reaction behind an atomic one. With scientists sharing information about the feasibility of a bomb, a crucial moment occurred in 1941, when Australian scientist Mark Oliphant met with American physicists in California.

title.children: An Australian helped shift Oppenheimer 'from the shadows of theory' to the Manhattan Project

image.altText: A view from above of the red roof of a building in a green forest with a large brown mudlside in front

items.synopsis: The landslide cut off roads into the area complicating rescue efforts with at least 25 people still missing as rescue efforts continue.

title.children: At least 11 dead after landslide in Georgian holiday destination

image.altText: Daniel Andrews wears a blue suit and white shirt and frowns while looking off camera.

items.synopsis: Many questions remain unanswered after Victoria walked away from the Commonwealth Games, and it's not just the premier's critics who are alarmed, writes state political reporter Richard Willingham.

title.children: Has Victoria's Commonwealth Games saga opened a 'Pandora's Box' for the Andrews government?

image.altText: A red-headed woman wearing a yellow patterned top holds up a Barbie doll, with hands adorned with red nail polish

items.synopsis: Ruth Handler was the ambitious career woman who created Barbie and changed America's toy industry. But a tax fraud scandal ultimately saw her forced out of the company she co-founded, Mattel.

title.children: The Barbie movie featured a tongue-in-cheek joke about the doll's creator. This is the story of Ruth Handler
